content.statement: A functor F: C→D is a structure-preserving mapping between categories that maps objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms, preserving composition and identities.

explanation.intuition: A functor is a 'translator' between categories. It takes an entire category's structure (objects and arrows) and maps it into another category, preserving all the relationships. Think of translating a road network from one country to another while keeping all connections intact.
explanation.key_insight: Functors are morphisms in the category of categories. They represent structure-preserving transformations at a higher level - not just between objects, but between entire mathematical worlds.
explanation.technical_details: A functor F: C→D consists of: (1) An object function: A ↦ F(A) for each object A in C, (2) A morphism function: (f: A→B) ↦ (F(f): F(A)→F(B)) for each morphism f in C. These must satisfy: F(id_A) = id_F(A) and F(g∘f) = F(g)∘F(f).

formal_definition.latex: \text{A functor } F: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D} \text{ consists of:} \\ \text{1. Object map: } F: \text{ob}(\mathcal{C}) \to \text{ob}(\mathcal{D}) \\ \text{2. Morphism map: } F: \text{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B) \to \text{hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F(A), F(B)) \\ \text{satisfying:} \\ F(\text{id}_A) = \text{id}_{F(A)} \\ F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)
components: Object mapping: F(A) for each object A
Morphism mapping: F(f) for each morphism f

sources.citation: Mac Lane, S. (1971). Categories for the Working Mathematician. Springer.
Awodey, S. (2010). Category Theory (2nd ed.). Oxford University Press.
